I. THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans to
the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the additional financing of the Bangladesh Power System 
Enhancement and Efficiency Improvement Project. 
2. The outcome of the ongoing project is to improve access to efficient and reliable electricity
supply in Bangladesh. The ongoing project includes four main outputs: (i) national transmission
network in southern Bangladesh strengthened (output 1); (ii) distribution network in Dhaka Electric
Supply Company Limited areas improved (output 2); (iii) distribution network in rural areas of
Bangladesh, including the capacity of end users, improved (output 3); and (iv) capacity in power
sector agencies enhanced (output 4). The proposed additional financing will further improve the
electricity distribution network in rural areas (output 3) in the Khulna division, one of the poorest
divisions in Bangladesh.1
II. THE PROJECT
A. Rationale
3. Performance  of  the  project.  The  proposed  project  meets  the  eligibility  criteria  for
additional financing as the overall project is (i) technically feasible, economically viable, and
financially sound; (ii) accorded high priority by the government; (iii) consistent with the project’s 
development objective; and (iv) consistent with the country partnership strategy for Bangladesh, 
2021–2023 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).2 The ongoing project is performing well as
(i) the project is rated on track under the project performance rating system; (ii) each safeguard
covenant item is complied with; (iii) delivery of expected outputs, including implementation of the
gender action plan, is rated successful; and (iv) the management of risks is rated successful as
all the risks included in the risk assessment and risk management plan have been managed
successfully. As of 18 September 2020, cumulative contract awards on the loans and grant were
$602.47 million (97.53%) while disbursements were $456.99 million (75.9%).3
4. Relevance of the project during COVID-19 pandemic. Reliable electricity supply is
lifeline infrastructure in rural areas both under normal circumstances and during and after the
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. During the COVID-19 restrictions, the electricity
supply has been one of the most critical inputs to support essential services, such as health care,
agricultural activities and food supply services, and online businesses for basic social needs.
Further, reliable electricity supply is essential for household activities during times of lockdown,
such as working from home and online education for school-age children.
5. COVID-19 has also significantly reduced the growth prospects of Bangladesh,4 and the
pandemic will ultimately impact the rural poor more since they are the most vulnerable and the
least resilient. Increased government spending is necessary to revive the economy. Infrastructure
spending on rural power distribution system improvements will generate local employment, help
maintain access by rural communities to health services and medical supplies, and enhance the
long-term growth prospects of the economy.

6. Suitability of using the additional financing modality. The additional financing is
strongly linked to the ongoing project’s outputs and outcome and provides efficiency gains by
expanding  the  scope  of  an  existing  output,  using  the  same  designs  and  implementation
arrangements and building upon the due diligence of the ongoing project.
7. Sector performance. About 50% of installed power generation capacity has private
sector investment. The transmission company and distribution company serving the capital city
have transformed into companies listed in the market to raise capital for investment needs. The
rural  electrification  subsector,  which  serves  low-income  customers,  adopts  the  consumers’
cooperative model. The sector has been progressing to decarbonize, as committed to in the
nationally  determined  contributions  for  Bangladesh,  by  improving  energy  efficiency  and
developing domestic renewable energy resources, among others.5 Also, Bangladesh, which is
already importing power from India, has plans to expand imports in the form of clean energy from
neighboring countries such as Bhutan and Nepal. This is supported under the South Asia
Subregional Economic Cooperation. 6
8. Strategic context. The overall project’s impact continues to be aligned with (i) the
government’s Perspective Plan of Bangladesh, 2010–2021: Making Vision 2021 a Reality,7 and
the 7th Five-Year Plan,8 which is accorded high priority by the government; (ii) ADB’s country
partnership strategy and country operations business plan, 2021–2023 for Bangladesh (footnote
2); and (iii) ADB’s Strategy 20309 by further improving access to efficient and reliable electricity
supply in the rural areas of Bangladesh.
B. Project Description
9. The impacts and outcome of the overall project will remain unchanged. The overall project
is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  100%  access  to  power  by  2021  and  power  sector
sustainability improved in Bangladesh by 2030.10 The project will have the following outcome:
access to efficient and reliable electricity supply in Bangladesh improved.11
10. The project will install an additional 990 kilometers (km) of 33 kilovolt (kV) and 3,000 km
of 11 kV below distribution lines and associated facilities, including 51 units of 33 kV/11 kV
substations in rural areas in Khulna division, which will expand output 3 (distribution network in
rural areas of Bangladesh improved) of the ongoing project. This will result in increasing electricity
access to 150,000 rural households.

C. Value Added by ADB
11. The overall project complements investments in power generation capacity by other
development partners and the private sector. These have contributed to improvements in the
reliability and coverage of electricity supply to rural and urban customers.
12. Capacity building support under the ongoing project and the associated policy dialogue
led to a tariff increase in February 2020, following an increase in 2017.12 This will help improve
the financial sustainability of the overall project and the Bangladesh Rural Electrification Board
(BREB). The proposed project will expand these efforts in the form of creating an inclusive working
environment by renovating the existing BREB’s offices with designs that cater to the elderly,
women,  children,  and  disabled  people.  This  includes  separate  toilets,  women’s  restrooms,
separate prayer rooms, and ramps for the disabled. The proposed project will also conduct a 
gender analysis of the BREB’s corporate structure and develop a corporate gender equality
strategy for the BREB.

17. The additional financing project is considered a climate mitigation project, and ADB will

E. Implementation Arrangements
18. The implementation arrangements of the ongoing project, such as the executing and
implementing agencies, will remain unchanged. The executing agency of the additional financing
project is the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources, and implementing agency is the
BREB,  which  distributes  the  electricity  in  rural  areas  in  Bangladesh.  The  same  project
implementation unit established within the BREB will be responsible for the implementation of the
additional financing project. The implementation period of the additional financing will be from
January 2021 to December 2025. The implementation arrangements are described in detail in
the PAM (footnote 13).

III. DUE DILIGENCE
A. Summary Due Diligence Results
19. A summary of the due diligence assessments for the proposed additional financing is
presented in Table 3. The full due diligence assessments are accessible from the list of linked
documents in Appendix 2.
Table 3: Summary of Due Diligence Assessments 
Area of 
Assessment  Summary of Assessment 
Technical  Technology to be utilized for the project is quite standard and is the same for the 
ongoing project. The BREB has broad experience in procurement, construction, 
and commissioning for this type of project. Therefore, the technology risk is low. 
Economic and  The project’s economic internal rate of return was estimated at 14.7% with the
financial viability  environmental benefits, well above the 9.0% economic cost of capital, making 
the project economically viable. Sensitivity testing indicated that the project is 
likely to remain sustainable in the face of adverse economic impact of various 
types. 
Financial analysis of the project indicated that the project is financially viable, with 
a financial internal rate of return of 2.6%, exceeding the weighted average cost 
of capital of 2.2%. Sensitivity analysis with 5% increase in capital cost, 5% 
increase in operation and maintenance cost, 3% increase in power purchase 
cost, 3% decrease in benefit, and 1-year delay in implementation showed that 
the project is sensitive in the case of changes in power purchase cost and benefit. 
Sustainability  The BREB has a well-established maintenance planning and budget allocation 
system. It has assigned 71 qualified staff members to operate and maintain the 
invested assets over the economic life. It has also gained extensive experience 
in operating and maintaining power distribution assets since its establishment in 
1977, and has received training from various donors. The electricity tariff is based 
on the tariff set by the Bangladesh Energy Regulatory Commission in February 
2020.a The utilities are required to file periodically for tariff increases to cover 
costs. This will help improve financial sustainability of the overall project and of 
the BREB. 
Governance  Financial management. The BREB has been performing satisfactorily on the 
ongoing project and will continue to handle all project financial matters for the 
additional financing. The updated financial management capacity assessment 
concluded that the overall project financial management risk is moderate. This 
rating  is  based  on  the  observation  that  the  project  implementation  unit  is 
well-established and functioning well. To further improve corporate governance, 
the BREB will continue to strengthen its internal audit function and enhance its 
information systems under the financial  management action plan, which is 
currently ongoing and supported by consultants hired under the ongoing loan. 
Procurement. Strategic procurement planning was conducted in January 2020 
and approved in September 2020 in accordance with ADB’s Guide on Assessing 
Procurement Risks and Determining Project Procurement Classification.b The 
project  procurement  classification  is  category  B  and  procurement  risk  is 
moderate. 
Anticorruption. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was
explained to and discussed with the government and the BREB. The specific 
policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the project 
administration manual.c

Assessment  Summary of Assessment 
Integrity due diligence. Risk assessment was conducted in January 2020. 
Based on the information provided, and in the absence of any other ongoing 
matter that could become an issue, the potential integrity and reputational risk 
arising from ADB’s association with the BREB is low to medium.
Poverty, social, and  The project area (Khulna division) is one of the poorest divisions in Bangladesh 
gender  (poverty rate of 27.7%). Improved access, quality, and reliability of the electricity 
supply in rural areas will help to (i) reduce household consumption of kerosene 
for cooking and lighting, thereby reducing household fuel expenditure; (ii) reduce 
the burden of household chores; (iii) catalyze energy-based economic activities, 
thereby improving household incomes; and (iv) improve the educational and 
medical environment. Farmers can reduce fuel expenditure for irrigation by 
switching diesel-powered pumps to electric pumps, which will help to reduce 
production costs. 
The gender mainstreaming category of the ongoing project and the proposed 
additional financing is classified effective gender mainstreaming as the project 
area under the additional financing is part of the ongoing project. Gender actions 
under the ongoing project are on track and will be continued under the additional 
financing.d In addition to the ongoing actions, a gender equality strategy for the 
BREB will be developed, and the existing BREB offices will be renovated to 
accommodate the elderly, women, children, and disabled people. 
Safeguards  The additional financing is classified B for environment, B for resettlement, and 
C for indigenous peoples. A total of 51 new substations will need 21.86 acres 
(8.85 hectares) of land. The land will be purchased through a willing buyer, willing 
seller process. The additional financing will not have impacts on legally protected 
areas or internationally or nationally important biodiversity areas or physical 
cultural resources. The updated resettlement plan and  initial environmental 
examination have been disclosed on the ADB website on 22 October 2020 and 
16 November 2020 respectively. Distribution lines do not have any significant 
environmental and social impacts as these usually follow the right-of-way of the 
existing roads. The project is not anticipated to impact on indigenous peoples, 
which has been confirmed during the project due diligence. Consultations have 
been undertaken during project preparation, and a two-tier grievance redress 
mechanism has been established under the ongoing loan and is functioning well. 
The project implementation unit will be supported by an environmental consultant 
and a social consultant for the additional financing. Environmental monitoring 
reports will be submitted semiannually during construction and annually during 
operation. Social monitoring reports will be submitted semiannually.

IV. ASSURANCES
21. The government and the BREB have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall
conform to all applicable ADB requirements including those concerning anticorruption measures,
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement
as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents.
22. The government and BREB have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project,
which are set forth in the draft loan agreements and project agreement.
V. RECOMMENDATION
23. I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve
(i) the loan of $70,000,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the additional
financing  of  the  Bangladesh  Power  System  Enhancement  and  Efficiency
Improvement Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with
interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate
(LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of
5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance
with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the
Board; and
(ii) the loan of $130,000,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the additional
financing  of  the  Bangladesh  Power  System  Enhancement  and  Efficiency
Improvement Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional
terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 2% per year during the grace period
and thereafter; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth
in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The outcome of the ongoing project is to improve access to efficient and reliable electricity supply in Bangladesh. The proposed additional financing will further improve the electricity distribution network in rural areas (output 3) in the Khulna division, one of the poorest divisions in Bangladesh.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated November 2020 is provided for the ADB project 49423-006 in Bangladesh.
